description:
Aspergillus brasiliensis CBS 101740 is a species of filamentous fungus belonging to the genus Aspergillus. It is a member of the Aspergillus section Nigri, which is a group of black-spored Aspergillus species.

Aspergillus brasiliensis is a common environmental fungus found in soil, decaying organic matter, and various food products. It is known for its ability to produce various secondary metabolites, including mycotoxins, which can have detrimental effects on human and animal health.

The CBS 101740 strain of A. brasiliensis was isolated from a soil sample collected in Brazil, hence the specific epithet "brasiliensis." This strain has been used in various scientific studies and is maintained in the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures (CBS) culture collection, a renowned repository for fungal strains.

Morphologically, A. brasiliensis CBS 101740 produces characteristic black-colored conidiophores and conidia, which are the asexual spores of the fungus. The colony growth on standard laboratory media is typically fast-growing and velvety in texture.

Genetically, A. brasiliensis CBS 101740 has been studied and found to possess a unique genomic profile within the Aspergillus section Nigri, which helps in its identification and taxonomic classification.

Overall, Aspergillus brasiliensis CBS 101740 is an important model organism for studying the biology, ecology, and potential applications or risks associated with this black-spored Aspergillus species.
